journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Enhancement in thermal properties of poly(vinyl alcohol) nanocomposites reinforced with Al2O3 nanoparticles

article-meta.aff: 1Organic Polymer Chemistry Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan, Islamic Republic of Iran
2Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials Institute, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan, Islamic Republic of Iran

author-notes.corresp: Shadpour Mallakpour, Organic Polymer Chemistry Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan, 84156-8311, Islamic Republic of Iran. Email: mallak@cc.iut.ac.ir

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In the present study, poly(vinyl alcohol)/Al2O3 nanocomposites of various compositions were produced through ultrasound-assisted technique. The nanocomposites were prepared by mixing a colloidal solution consisting of Al2O3 nanoparticles with a water solution of poly(vinyl alcohol) and then hybrids films with different contents of inorganic phase were obtained after solvent evaporation. Field emission scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, and UV-visible spectroscopy were utilized to characterize the poly(vinyl alcohol)/Al2O3 nanocomposites morphology and properties. Thermogravimetric analysis and UV-visible results indicated that the thermal stability is enhanced distinctly, without a sacrifice in optical clarity. The improvement of thermal properties was attributed to the homogeneous and good dispersion of Al2O3 nanoparticles in the poly(vinyl alcohol) matrix and the strong hydrogen bonding between O–H groups of poly(vinyl alcohol) and the oxygen atoms of nanoparticles. On the whole, the poly(vinyl alcohol)/Al2O3 nanocomposite systems had thermal properties, which were superior to that of the neat polymer and its conventionally filled composites.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Organic–inorganic nanohybrids have recently received great attention. The idea is to combine advantages of organic materials such as light weight as well as flexibility and advantages of inorganic material that are mechanical strength, thermal stability and chemical resistance.1

With increasing interest in the use of biodegradable and sustainable substitutes for mass applications, poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) provides an attractive point of proportional study on an oil-based synthetic material with the properties of a ‘green polymer’.2,3 PVA has been largely studied owing to its good film-forming ability, high hydrophilicity, biocompatibility, good chemical resistance and interesting mechanical properties.4,5 These properties have led to a wide range of industrial products such as membrane, textile sizing and finishing, adhesive, coatings and paints.6 Lately, the interest has been focused on its promising biomedical applications such as drug delivery systems,7,8 dialysis membrane,9 wound dressing,10 scaffolds for tissue engineering,11 contact lenses, and artificial organs.12,13 These applications stimulate an interest in improving of the thermal, mechanical, and barrier properties of nanocomposite (NC) films, with retaining the optical clarity of PVA.

Alumina (Al2O3) and other oxides are widely found in many applications including support for catalysts,14 organometallic,15 metal-organic and luminescent compounds,16 formulations for dental applications,17 additives for polymer NCs,18,19 ceramic membranes,20 and stationary phases for chromatography.21 Al2O3 is the most cost effective and widely used material in the family of engineering ceramics. It has excellent properties like hard, wear-resistant, excellent dielectric properties, resists strong acid and alkali attack at elevated temperatures, good thermal conductivity, excellent size and shape capability, high strength and stiffness, etc.22 With this exceptional combination of properties and an attractive price, it has a very wide range of applications i.e. gas laser tubes, wear pads, seal rings, high temperature electrical insulators, high voltage insulators, furnace liner tubes, thread and wire guides, electronic substrates, ballistic armor, abrasion-resistant tube and elbow liners, thermometry sensors, laboratory instrument tubes and sample holders, instrumentation parts for thermal property test machines, grinding media, etc.23–25 Although, Al2O3 is present in many forms like, α, χ, η, δ, κ, θ, γ, ρ, these arise during the heat treatment of aluminium hydroxide or aluminium oxy-hydroxide, but the most thermodynamically stable form is α-Al2O3.22 That is why it is used in the present investigation.

PVA has been extensively investigated as a matrix for different kinds of nanofillers such as: clay, Ag nanoparticles (NPs), Fe3O4, carbon nanotube, graphite, titanium dioxide, nanocellulose and zinc oxide.26–32

In recent years, sonochemical processing has been recognized to be a useful technique for generation novel materials with unusual properties.33 This technique has been explored as a very attractive and alternative tool for preparation of various nanosized materials, such as carbides, oxides, sulfides, and composite NPs. Based on sonochemical theory the ultrasonication of a liquid could generate hot spots as high as 5000 K, and local pressure as high as 500 atm, and also heating and cooling rate greater than 10−9 K/s. Therefore, ultrasonic irradiation can produced a very harsh environment that can induce some chemical reactions that cannot take place under usual conditions and could be extensively applied in the homogenous dispersion of NPs in organic polymers.34–37

In our previous studies, PVA/organoclay and PVA/TiO2 NCs were prepared via ultrasonic irradiation methods.38,39 The objective of the present work is to study the feasibility of another NC using biodegradable PVA and α-Al2O3 with improved thermal properties for engineering applications. PVA/α-Al2O3 NC films were fabricated via dispersion different amount of the α-Al2O3 (5, 10, and 15 wt%) in PVA matrix via ultrasonic process and following by solution film casting method. The resulting hybrid films were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and UV-visible transmission spectra techniques. Dispersion of the nanosized Al2O3 into the PVA matrix is expected to increase the physical and thermal properties of the resulting materials.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: PVA (99% hydrolysis, weight-average molecular weight = 72,000 g/mol) was purchased from Merck Chemical Co. Nanosized α-Al2O3 powder was purchased from Neutrino Co. with an average particle size of 30–50 nm.

sec.title: Equipments
sec.p: The reaction was carried out on a MISONIX ultrasonic liquid processors, XL-2000 SERIES. Ultrasound was a wave of frequency 2.25 × 104 Hz and power of 100 W.

FT-IR spectra were recorded on Jasco-680 (Japan) spectrophotometer with 2 cm−1 resolution. The KBr pellet technique was applied for monitoring changes in the FT-IR spectra of the samples in the range of 4000–400 cm−1. The vibrational transition frequencies are reported in wavenumbers (cm-1).

XRD patterns were recorded on a Philips X’PERT MPD with a copper target operating at current of 100 mA and a voltage of 45 kV and Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.1542 nm) in the range of 5° –80° at the speed of 0.05°/min.
TGA was performed on a STA503 WinTA instrument in a nitrogen atmosphere by heating rate of 10°C/min from ambient temperature to 800°C at nitrogen atmosphere.
Surface morphology of the samples was characterized using FE-SEM (HITACHI: S-4160).
The dispersion of the Al2O3 in PVA matrix has been controlled by TEM. The TEM images were obtained from a Philips CM120 using an accelerator voltage of 100 kV.

sec.title: Preparation of PVA/Al2O3 NCs
sec.p: For preparation of PVA/Al2O3 NCs, different amounts of Al2O3 NPs (5, 10, and 15 wt%) were mixed with 0.1 g of PVA. The mixture was dispersed in 15 mL of absolute ethanol and then sonicated for 2 h. The solvent was removed and the white solid was dried in vacuum at 60°C for 3 h.

sec.title: Preparation of PVA/Al2O3 NC films
sec.p: The NC films were fabricated by casting from aqueous solution. At first, the prepared NC with different amount of Al2O3 NPs were dissolved in distilled water at 70°C to prepare the 5 wt% solution and then it was sonicated for 30 min. The resulting mixtures were cast in glass Petri dishes. Bubbles were removed by shaking and blowing air. The cast Petri dishes were kept at room temperature until dried. The films were peeled out and dried at 60°C under vacuum for 2 h. The thickness of the films was 0.1–0.2 mm.

sec.title: Preparation of PVA/Al2O3 NCs
sec.p:
The utilization of high intensity ultrasound offers a facile, versatile synthetic tool for nanostructure materials that are often unavailable by conventional methods. Synthesis of PVA/Al2O3 NCs was performed via an ultrasonic irradiation process. Due to the high local pressure and temperature which produce during sonication, the Al2O3 NPs could be dispersed and will combine with PVA. When Al2O3 NPs are embedded into PVA matrix, the hydroxyl groups of Al2O3 can condense with hydroxyl group of PVA. Therefore, there are chemical or hydrogen bonds in the interface between Al2O3 and PVA chains; consequently, the dispersity of NPs could be greatly improved as can be observed in Figure 1. Different amounts of Al2O3 NPs were mixed with the PVA and the mixture was dispersed in absolute ethanol, under ultrasonic irradiation. After that, the resulting suspension was concentrated by slow evaporating of the ethanol and dried at room temperature. The solid was collected and further dried under vacuum. Figure 1.
Interaction between PVA and Al2O3 NPs.
PVA: poly(vinyl alcohol); NPs: nanoparticles.

sec.title: FT-IR spectra investigation
sec.p:
To reveal the interactions between Al2O3 NPs and PVA chains, FT-IR spectra of pure PVA and PVA/Al2O3 hybrid were acquired, and shown in Figure 2. For the Al2O3 NPs, the characteristic peaks in the FT-IR spectra present near at 3300–3400 cm−1 and 1628 cm−1 indicate the stretching vibration and bending vibration of hydroxyl group peaks on the Al2O3 particles’ surface, respectively (Figure 2). Also, the broad absorption peak from 400 to 1000 cm−1 is attributed to the characteristic absorption band of Al2O3. Neat PVA shows a broad absorption peak around 3100–3500 cm−1, which is due to the presence of hydroxyl group of PVA molecules and adsorbed water. The absorption peaks in the region of 2942 cm−1 are due to stretching vibrations of –CH and CH2 groups and at 1420 cm−1 may correspond to vibration of CH2 bond in PVA molecules (Figure 2). The band observed at 1713 cm−1 is as a result of the carbonyl functional groups of residual acetate groups remaining after the manufacture of PVA from hydrolysis of poly(vinyl acetate). The incorporation Al2O3 NPs in PVA caused the slight changes in the intensities of absorption bands as well as the formation of new absorption bands in the range of 600–400 cm−1 is attributed to the Al–O stretching. This result confirmed the existence of Al2O3 NPs in the PVA matrix. In the spectra of PVA/Al2O3 NCs, whit increasing the Al2O3 content, the stretching of –OH bands at 3000–3500 cm−1 range is decreasing. This region is attributed to a wide distribution of hydrogen bonding among the hydroxyl groups of PVA. This fact confirms the presence of hydrogen bonding between PVA and Al2O3 NPs. Figure 2.
FT-IR spectra of Al2O3, neat PVA and different NC films.
FT-IR: Fourier transform infrared; PVA: poly(vinyl alcohol); NC: nanocomposite.

sec.title: XRD patterns
sec.p:
One well-established method for characterizing organic–inorganic hybrids is the use of XRD. The crystallinity of the PVA/Al2O3 NC films was studied via the XRD test. The XRD pattern of neat PVA, α-Al2O3, NC5%, NC10% and NC15% are shown in Figure 3. In the neat PVA, due to the high hydrogen bond of hydroxyl groups, a semicrystalline structure was exhibited. Two peaks for the PVA were found, one peak with high intensity appears at about 2θ = 19.5° and another peak with low intensity appears at about 2θ = 41° (Figure 3(a)). The XRD pattern of the as received α-Al2O3 powder shows good agreement with the reference XRD pattern (42-1468 JCPDS file) (Figure 3(b)). Meanwhile, in the PVA/Al2O3 NC films, the diffraction peaks of α-Al2O3 are unchanged at 2θ, and show diffraction patterns similar to those of pure α-Al2O3. This indicates that the α-Al2O3 remains stable after being doped into the PVA matrix. However, all the diffraction peaks were broadened. These characteristic peaks are assigned in Figure 3(c) to (e). The average crystalline size of Al2O3 NPs, which has been determined from the half width of the diffraction using the Debye–Scherrer equation (D = Kλ/βcosθ) is approximately 38 nm, where D is the crystallite size, λ is wavelength of the radiation, θ is the Bragg’s angle and β is the full width at half maximum. According to the figures, the peak intensity at 2θ = 19.5° for PVA is reduced when surface Al2O3 NPs are added. This indicate that the crystallinity of PVA matrix reduced by the addition of Al2O3 nanofillers. As a result from this XRD data, it is understood that Al2O3 may be connected to PVA chain via covalent bond. Figure 3.
XRD patterns of: (a) neat PVA, (b) α-Al2O3, (c) NC5%, (d) NC10% and (e) NC15%.
XRD: X-ray diffraction; PVA: poly(vinyl alcohol); NC: nanocomposite.

sec.title: Field emission scanning electron microscopy
sec.p:
In order to study the microstructures and nanofiller distribution within the NCs, FE-SEM and TEM analysis were performed. Figure 4 showed FE-SEM photographs of the 5 wt%, 10 wt% and 15 wt% PVA/Al2O3 NCs. From these photographs, it was observed that Al2O3 NPs were dispersed in the PVA matrix, because, the Al2O3 nanofiller having excellent adhesion and strong interfacial bonding to the PVA beads. For NCs with 5% and 10% of Al2O3 NPs, the FE-SEM images show that most of the Al2O3 NPs are homogeneously dispersed in the polymer matrix and their sizes are estimated to be between 30 and 50 nm (Figure 4(a) to (f)). They also indicate that there is a good adhesion between organic and inorganic phases and the distance between Al2O3 NPs is much larger than the diameter of the NPs. In addition, the results demonstrate that the structure of the prepared hybrid films of NC5% and NC10% are more compact and uniform than that of NC15%. This morphological change can be attributed to the re-ordered crystalline phase of the PVA matrix, causing a packed network. Figure 4.
FE-SEM photographs of: (a-c) PVA/Al2O3 NC5%, (d-f) NC10% and (g-i) NC15%.
FE-SEM: field emission scanning electron microscopy; PVA: poly(vinyl alcohol); NC: nanocomposite.

sec.title: Transmission electron microscopy
sec.p:
The TEM is used to directly view the hybrid structure for the nanocomposites formed, with the emphasis on the dispersion of the nanometer-thin layered fillers in the polymer matrix. It is a complement to XRD and SEM results. Figure 5 illustrates the TEM images of PVA/Al2O3 NC (10 wt%) with different magnification, where the dark areas represent the Al2O3 NPs and the gray/white areas represent the PVA matrix. These Figures show that the diameter distribution of NPs were narrow with spherical shape and the NPs have the diameter about 30–40 nm in the NC10%. These results indicating that the hydroxy groups in PVA must have played the major role in dispersing of the Al2O3 NPs in the matrix. Figure 5.
TEM micrographs of PVA/Al2O3 NC containing 10 wt% Al2O3.
TEM: transmission electron microscopy; PVA: poly(vinyl alcohol); NC: nanocomposite.

sec.title: Thermal degradation properties
sec.p:
TGA curves and data of the pure PVA and its NCs were shown on Figure 6 and Table 1, respectively. According to TGA result, the thermal degradation behaviors of pure PVA and NCs with different percent of Al2O3 pass through one minor and two major weight loss steps when heated from room temperature to 800°C. The first weight loss takes place at about 100–200°C, that the reason for the weight loss may be caused by the evaporation of adsorbed moisture and/or trapped solvent due to the interactions among PVA and water as shown in Figure 6. The first major weight loss step at 200–400°C involves the elimination reactions of H2O or the polymer dehydration and formation of a ‘polyacetylene-like’ structure. The second major degradation step at 400–550°C maybe corresponds to the decomposition of main chain of PVA and includes the further degradation of polyene residues to yield the carbon and hydrocarbons. Table 1 shows the residual weight (wt%) of PVA and different NCs at three steps of weight loss. According to this table, the residual weight was increased by the addition of Al2O3 NPs on PVA matrix. Figure 6.
TGA thermogram of PVA and PVA/Al2O3 NCs.
TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; PVA: poly(vinyl alcohol); NC: nanocomposite. Table 1.
The data obtained from TGA thermogram of PVA and NCs film-residual mass at different step weight loss
Sample name 100–200°C 200–400°C 400–550°C Char yield (%)a LOIb
PVA 98.0 23.1 8.0 7.1 20.3
NC5% 98.7 30.0 14.5 13.8 23.0
NC10% 98.7 34.3 17.4 16.3 24.0
NC15% 99.0 40.0 24 22.5 26.5
a
Weight percent of the material left undecomposed after TGA at maximum temperature 800°C in a N2 atmosphere. b
LOI evaluated at char yield at 800°C.
TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; PVA: poly(vinyl alcohol); NC: nanocomposite; LOI: limiting oxygen index.

Char yield at 800°C and limiting oxygen index (LOI) based on Van Krevelen and Hoftyzer equation40 of the PVA and different NCs are also summarized in Table 1. According to this data, PVA film shows 7% residue at 800°C, while the NC films show 14–22% residue at this temperature. The increase of char is due to the alumina incorporation into the PVA matrix in the hybrid materials. In additional, the Al2O3 is a nanoscale particle, which offers a larger surface area and improves the effect of thermal cover.

sec.title: Optical clarity of PVA and PVA/Al2O3 NCs
sec.p:
The transmission spectra of pure PVA, PVA/Al2O3 NC films by different Al2O3 content (5%, 10% and 15%) were studied in the regions of 200–800 nm. The films used for optical property measurements are prepared to have thickness of 0.1–02 mm. PVA showed high transparency in UV/Vis spectra, when the Al2O3 was added visible light still can transmit through the NC films. As shown in Figure 7 the optical clarity of PVA film is slightly affected by the presence of the low Al2O3 content. With the addition of Al2O3, the material appeared semitransparent to eye observation. Finally, in order to better visualize the resulting light transmittance of the NC films, each of the samples is placed directly on top of a pattern to show the film transparencies. The resulting photo is also shown in Figure 7. It is fascinating to mention that, the PVA/Al2O3 5 wt% NC on Figure 7 was the most transparent, although some haziness could still be observed. Furthermore, even the 10 wt% NC is still relatively transparent. Figure 7.
UV/Vis transmittance spectra of PVA and PVA/Al2O3 hybrids containing 5, 10 and 15 wt% of Al2O3 NPs.
PVA: poly(vinyl alcohol); NPs: nanoparticles.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, a series of PVA/Al2O3 hybrid films was prepared by ultrasonic-assistance method. Results of microstructure and performance analysis indicate that the Al2O3 NPs were disperses in the PVA matrix. The combination of FTIR spectroscopy, XRD, FE-SEM, TEM, UV/Vis and thermal methods verified the formation of Al2O3 NPs and PVA/Al2O3 NCs. According to XRD results, the Al2O3 phase maintains its crystal structure after being doped into the PVA matrix, showing good particle stability. Thermal stability from TGA measurements was shown to be enhanced compared with those of pure PVA. The improvement of thermal properties was attributed to the homogeneous and good dispersion of Al2O3 NPs in polymeric matrix and the strong hydrogen bonding between O–H groups of PVA and the O–H groups of the Al2O3 NPs. The morphology of the o NCs show that the Al2O3 NPs are well-distributed within the PVA matrix and oriented along the PVA axis.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received partial financial support from the Research Affairs Division Isfahan University of Technology (IUT), Isfahan. Further financial support from National Elite Foundation (NEF), Iran Nanotechnology Initiative Council (INIC) and Center of Excellency in Sensors and Green Chemistry Research (IUT) is also gratefully acknowledged.
